description: A catastrophic decline in the population of the Taíno people of the Caribbean, particularly on the island of Hispaniola, due to European colonization, disease, exploitation, and forced labor.

systems_imposed.encomienda: Forced many Taíno to work in fields and mines in exchange for protection, education, and seasonal salary.
systems_imposed.forced_labor: Introduced by Ponce de León, leading to Taíno rebellions.

population_decline.description: In thirty years, between 80% and 90% of the Taíno population died.

causes.disease: Massive decline due to infectious diseases (smallpox, influenza, measles, typhus).
causes.forced_labor: Lethal forced labor in mines significantly contributed to deaths.
causes.food_shortage: Conversion of Taíno cultivation to Spanish methods and refusal by some Taínos to plant or harvest led to famine.

scholarly_perspective.doubts_on_early_estimates: Researchers doubt Las Casas' figures for the pre-contact levels of the Taíno population.
scholarly_perspective.comparison_to_european_rebound: Lack of rebound for indigenous populations compared to Europe's post-Black Death recovery.
scholarly_perspective.slavery_as_major_killer: Slavery and exploitation on an enormous scale emerged as major killers of the Taíno people.

cultural_impact.Taíno_culture: Deeply affected and significantly diminished due to the genocide and subsequent social changes.

historical_narratives.Bartolomé_de_las_Casas: Recorded the dramatic population decline and criticized the Spanish treatment of the Taíno.

modern_assessment.genocide_recognition: Many historians and academics recognize the events as a form of genocide against the Taíno people.
modern_assessment.forced_labor_impact: Anthropologists and historians conclude that forced labor in mines was a significant cause of death.

references.title: A Orillas del Mar Caribe: Boceto histórico de la Playa de Ponce
references.author: Eli D. Oquendo-Rodríguez
